subsection.title: Growth Factors
subsection.p: Researchers often use cell lines from the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster to study protein interactions related to cancer and other diseases. From 60% to 70% of human disease genes are found in Drosophila cells, and gene discoveries in the flies have led to parallel studies in vertebrates.

One milliliter of culture contains about 1 million Drosophila cells, and the population doubles every 24 hours. The table shows the population, P(t), of Drosophila cells, in millions, as a function of time in days.
t 0 1 2 3 4 5 6
P(t) 1 2 4 8 16 32 64

The function describes exponential growth. During each time interval of a fixed length the population is multiplied by a certain constant amount, in this case by 2. Because the population grew by a factor of 2 every day, we say that 2 is the growth factor for the function. Functions that describe exponential growth can be expressed in a standard form.

assemblage.title: Exponential Growth
assemblage.p: The function P(t)=P_0 b^t describes exponential growth, where P_0=P(0) is the initial value of the function and b is the growth factor.

subsection.p: For the Drosophila cell population, we have P(t)=1 \cdot 2^t so P_0 = 1 and b=2. You can see that the graph of the function is not linear. In fact, the population grows slowly at first, but eventually grows faster and faster.

statement.p:
In 1985, there were about 1.2 million cell phone users world-wide. Since that time, the number has grown by a factor of 1.5 each year.
Make a table of values and graph the function.
Write a formula for the number, C(t), of cell phone users t years after 1985.
How many cell phone users does the formula predict for the year 2000?

li.p:
We let t=0 in 1985, so C(0)=1.2, in millions. Each value of C(t) can be obtained by multiplying the previous value by the growth factor, 1.5.
t 0 1 2 3 4 5 6 7
C(t) 1.2 1.8 2.7 4.05 6.08 9.1 13.7 20.5
1.2 \times 1.5 = 1.8 1.8 \times 1.5 = 2.7 2.7 \times 1.5 = 4.05 4.05 \times 1.5 = 6.08 6.08 \times 1.5 = 9.1 9.1 \times 1.5 = 13.7 13.7 \times 1.5 = 20.5

solution.li: The initial value of the function is C_0 = C(0) = 1.2 million. The annual growth factor is b=1.5, so the formula is C(t) = 1.2(1.5)^t

The year 2000 is 15 years after 1985, so we evaluate the function for \alert{15}t=. C(\alert{15}) = 1.2(1.5)^{\alert{15}} = 525.47 The formula predicts that over 525 million people used cell phones in 2000.

li.p: A negative exponent does not mean that the power is negative! For example, 2^{-3}\ne -2^3

statement.p:
True or false.
Negative exponents are used to denote reciprocals.
We can write \dfrac{1}{4x^3} as 4x^{-3}.
Any number raised to the zero power is zero.
(-4)^{-3}=4^3

Write each expression without using negative exponents.
5^{-4}=
5x^{-4}=

subsection.p: In the next example, we see how to evaluate expressions that contain negative exponents and how to solve equations involving negative exponents.

statement.p:
The body mass index, or BMI, is one measure of a person’s physical fitness. Your body mass index is defined by \text{BMI} = wh^{-2} where w is your weight in kilograms and h is your height in meters. The World Health Organization classifies a person as obese if his or her BMI is 25 or higher.
Calculate the BMI for a woman who is 1.625 meters (64 inches) tall and weighs 54 kilograms (120 pounds).
For a fixed weight, how does BMI vary with height?
The world’s heaviest athlete is the amateur sumo wrestler Emanuel Yarbrough, who weighs 319 kg (704 pounds). What height would Yarbrough have to be to have a BMI under 25?

li.p: We evaluate the formula to find \text{BMI} = 54(1.625^{-2})= 54(\dfrac{1}{1.625^2})= 20.45
\text{BMI} = wh^{-2} = \dfrac{w}{h^2}, so BMI varies inversely with the square of height. That is, for a fixed weight, BMI decreases as height increases.

subsection.title: Power Functions
subsection.p: The functions that describe direct and inverse variation are part of a larger family of functions called power functions.

assemblage.title: Power Function
assemblage.p: A function of the form f(x) = kx^p where k and p are nonzero constants, is called a power functionpower function.

subsection.p: Examples of power functions are V(r ) = \frac{4}{3}\pi r^3 ~~\text{ and }~~L(T ) = 0.8125T^2 In addition, the basic functions f (x) = \frac{1}{x} ~~\text{ and }~~ g(x) = \frac{1}{x^2} which we studied in can be written as f (x) = x^{-1} ~~\text{ and }~~ g(x) = x^{-2} Their graphs are shown below. Note that the domains of power functions with negative exponents do not include zero.

image.description: graphs of the two basic reciprocal functions

li.p: This is not a power function, because of the addition of the constant term.
We can write g(x) = \frac{1}{3}x^{-4}, so g is a power function.
This is not a power function, but it can be treated as the sum of two power functions, because h(x) = x^{-2} + 6x^{-3}.

statement.p:
True or false.
The exponent in a power function must be positive.
Direct and inverse variation are examples of power functions.
If f is a power function, then f(0)=0.
The sum of two power functions is not always a power function.
Write each function as a power function in the form y = kx ^p.
For this exercise, enter rational numbers in decimal form. For example, enter "0.5" rather than "1/2".

subsection.p: Most applications are concerned with positive variables only, so many models use only the portion of the graph in the first quadrant.

statement.p:
The intensity of the radiation from our Sun varies inversely with distance.
Use a negative exponent to write a formula for the intensity I as a function of d,~I=f(d).
The planet Mercury is 0.387 AU (Astronomical Units) distant from the Sun, and the intensity of radiation at its surface is 9147 watts per square meter. Find the constant of proportionality in the formula for I.
Graph I=f(d).
Earth is 1 AU from the sun. What is the intensity of the Sun's radiation at the surface of the Earth?
The surface of Jupiter receives 50.63 watts per square meter of the Suns' radiation. How far is Jupiter from the Sun?

ol.label: a
ol.li: If we use k for the constant of proportionality, then I=\dfrac{k}{d^2}. Rewriting this equation with a negative exponent gives I=kd^{-2}.
We evaluate the function for several values of d, and use a calculator to obtain the graph shown. graph
We substitute d=1 into the formula to obtain I=1370(1)^{-2} = 1370 Earth receives 1370 watts/m^2 of solar radiation.

subsection.p: The function I = \dfrac{k}{d^2} is an example of an inverse square lawinverse square law, because I varies inversely with the square of d. Such laws are fairly common in physics and its applications, because gravitational and other forces behave in this way. Here is another example of an inverse square law.

statement.p: Cell phone towers typically transmit signals at 10 watts of power. The signal strength varies inversely with the square of distance from the tower, and 1 kilometer away the signal strength is 0.8 picowatt. (A picowatt is 10^{-12} watt.) Cell phones can receive a signal as small as 0.01 picowatt. How far can you be from the nearest tower and still hope to have cell phone reception?

subsection.title: Working with Negative Exponents
subsection.p: For reference, we restate the laws of exponents below. The laws are valid for all integer exponents m and n, and for a,~b \not= 0.

md.mrow: \text{a}\amp. ~x^3\cdot x^{-5} = x^{3-5} = x^{-2} \amp\amp \blert{\text{Apply the first law: Add exponents.}}

subsection.p: You can check that each of the calculations in is shorter when we use negative exponents instead of converting the expressions into algebraic fractions.

statement.p:
Simplify by applying the laws of exponents. Write without negative exponents.
\left(2a^{-4}\right) \left(-4a^2\right)=
\dfrac{(r^2)^{-3}}{3r^{-4}}=

subsection.p: In the opening table we saw that 2^0 = 1, and in fact a^0 = 1 as long as a \ne 0. Now we can see that this definition is consistent with the laws of exponents. The quotient of any (nonzero) number divided by itself is 1. But by applying the second law of exponents, we also have 1 = \frac{a^m}{a^m}= a^{m-m} = a^0

statement.p:
True or false.
We cannot add or subtract terms with different exponents.
(a+b)^5=a^5+b^5 is an application of the fourth law of exponents.
If x \not= 0, then \dfrac{k}{x^{-n}} = kx^n.
(x^2)^{-3} = (x^{-2})^3 because \dfrac{1}{x^2 \cdot x^2 \cdot x^2} = (\dfrac{1}{x^2})(\dfrac{1}{x^2})(\dfrac{1}{x^2}) .

subsection.title: Review of Scientific Notation
subsection.p: Scientists and engineers regularly encounter very large numbers such as, 5,980,000,000,000,000,000,000,000, (the mass of the earth in kilograms) and very small numbers such as 0.000~ 000~ 000~ 000~ 000~ 000~ 000 ~001~~/Pretext/mathbook/script/mbx -c webwork -d wwscratch -s https://webwork-ptx.aimath.org test-section.xml xsltproc --xinclude --stringparam webwork.extraction ~/Pretext/int-alg/wwscratch/webwork-extraction.xml ~/PreText/mathbook/xsl/pretext-merge.xsl test-section.xml > merge.xml xsltproc --xinclude ~/Pretext/int-alg/xsl/int-alg-html.xsl merge.xml 67 (the mass of a hydrogen atom in grams) in their work. These numbers are easier to use when expressed in scientific notation.

assemblage.title: To Write a Number in Scientific Notation

ol.li: Locate the decimal point so that there is exactly one nonzero digit to its left.

li.p:
Count the number of places you moved the decimal point: this determines the power of 10.
If the original number is greater than 10, the exponent is positive.
If the original number is less than 1, the exponent is negative.

statement.p:
Write each number in scientific notation.
478,000
0.00032

md.mrow: 478,000 \amp = 4.78000 \times 10^5 \amp \amp \blert{\text{Move the decimal 5 places to the left.}}
0.00032 \amp = 00003.2 \times 10^{-4} \amp \amp \blert{\text{Move the decimal 4 places to the right.}}

statement.p:
Write each number in scientific notation.
0.063
1480

subsection.p: Your calculator displays numbers in scientific notation if they are too large or too small to fit in the display screen. Try squaring the number 123,456,789 on your calculator. Enter 123456789~~\boxed{x^2} and the calculator will display the result as 1.524157875~~\text{E}~~16 This is how the calculator displays the number 1.524157875 \times 10^{16}. Notice that the power 10^{16} is displayed as E 16.
To enter a number in scientific form, we use the key labeled \boxed{\text{EE}}. For example, to enter 3.26 \times 10^{-18} we enter the keying sequence 3.26~~ \boxed{\text{EE}} ~~ \boxed{(-)} ~~ 18

statement.p: In 2019, the average American ate 98.6 kilograms of meat. It takes about 16 kilograms of grain to produce one kilogram of meat, and advanced farming techniques can produce about 6000 kilograms of grain on each hectare of arable land. (A hectare is 10,000 square meters, or just under two and a half acres.) Now, the total land area of the Earth is about 13 billion hectares, but only about 11% of that land is arable. Is it possible for each of the 7.8 billion people on Earth to eat as much meat as Americans do?
